item.title: Will You Save With Fractional Line Services?
item.description: You might think ordering less bandwidth would save you money, but when it comes to telecom lines, that’s not always the case. While getting a fraction of a T1 line’s capacity seemed like a good idea for those who didn’t need the full 1.5 Mbps, the cost savings weren’t as significant as one might expect. The issue is that the infrastructure for a T1 line, the “pipe,” has a fixed capacity regardless of actual usage.

item.title: Increase Bandwidth Without Increasing Costs
item.description: Companies need more bandwidth, especially for their wide area networks (WANs), but it can be very expensive. While high speeds are affordable within a company’s LAN, connecting to the outside world traditionally comes with much higher costs. This is because WAN connections were typically provided by telecom companies using technology initially meant for phone services. While more modern providers have entered the market with updated infrastructure, even traditional providers are adapting to the demand for data services.

item.title: Business Ethernet Vs T1
item.description: For decades, small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) have relied heavily on T1 lines. However, a new service called Business Ethernet is emerging as a strong competitor, offering comparable performance at a lower cost. Business Ethernet, also referred to as Metro Ethernet, Ethernet over Copper, or Ethernet over Fiber, provides advantages such as scalable bandwidth options, reduced cost per Mbps, and wider availability. Its name emphasizes that Ethernet is no longer limited to Local Area Networks (LANs) and carriers, as it’s rapidly being adopted by SMBs.

item.title: Is Metro Ethernet Available?
item.description: When your company needs more bandwidth, you might wonder about your options. Metro Ethernet is a popular choice, often providing more bandwidth for less money than traditional telecommunications services. But is it available in your area? You can easily check availability using an Ethernet service finder to view a map of “lit” buildings nearby. A lit building has active fiber optic service, meaning the fiber optic cables are installed and operational with active laser light.

item.title: Lit Buildings Have Near Infinite Bandwidth
item.description: By: John Shepler When choosing a business location, consider “lit buildings” for their exceptional connectivity. These buildings are already equipped with fiber optic internet infrastructure, offering a solution to bandwidth concerns. What Does “Lit Building” Mean? “Lit building” signifies a building pre-wired for fiber optic internet and potentially point-to-point bandwidth services. The term “lit” references the laser beams used to transmit digital signals at high speeds through fiber optic cables.

item.title: Point to Point Lines Connect Dealerships
item.description: Many businesses, from car dealerships to restaurants, benefit from having multiple locations. However, managing these locations as a unified company requires connecting them effectively. Point-to-point lines and MPLS networks offer solutions for this need. Consider a car dealership expanding by acquiring another dealership. While this offers strategic advantages, consolidating operations like accounting, marketing, and IT can lead to cost savings. Centralizing these functions requires reliable and efficient connectivity between locations.

item.title: Fiber Optic Leased Lines for Business
How Maestro Smart Antenna Improves Fixed Wireless
item.description: Accel Technologies, a branch of Accel Networks, is launching a groundbreaking product for fixed wireless connections: the Maestro smart antenna system. Maestro aims to make 3G and 4G fixed wireless broadband a more attractive alternative to pricier business connectivity options like T1, MPLS, VSAT, Frame Relay, and point-to-point microwave services. What makes Maestro so special? Like other smart devices, Maestro utilizes active technology to enhance performance. In this situation, it improves the performance of a typically passive component: the RF antenna.

item.title: Cyber Monday is For Business Buyers Too
item.description: By: John Shepler Cyber Monday is known for online shopping deals that shoppers couldn’t get in crowded stores during Black Friday sales. While there are many consumer deals, businesses need to consider their savings opportunities as well. Business spending is a significant part of the economy, and their savings can lead to lower prices for consumers. Taking advantage of Cyber Monday bargains is a win-win situation for everyone. Businesses should explore potential savings on services they might not typically consider.

item.description: By: John Shepler With economic uncertainty looming, businesses must prioritize survival. Focusing on expense reduction is crucial when future income is unpredictable. Telecom expenses, including data, phone, and internet services, often represent a significant monthly cost. It’s highly probable that you’re overpaying for these services. Who’s Gouging Me? item.title: Wireless Internet Access For Farms
item.description: While living and working on a farm has its perks, getting reliable broadband internet can be a challenge. Conventional options like DSL and Cable might not be feasible due to distance limitations, often leaving farms outside their service areas. Don’t worry, there are other solutions for obtaining reasonably priced internet access in rural areas. These alternatives focus on services that overcome distance barriers or eliminate the need for physical cables.

item.title: 4G Wireless Broadband Options
Lock In Telecom Cost Savings For Next Year
item.description: As we wrap up the year and analyze our performance, it’s common to wonder if we’re overspending on business operations, especially networking and telecom. A thorough market analysis often reveals opportunities to secure better rates for the same services. By doing this now, you can lock in savings for the entire next year. Why are such savings possible? Primarily, increased competition and technological advancements. Previously, businesses were limited to local telephone companies for their communication needs.

item.title: Do You Still Have Broadband?
item.description: By: John Shepler Internet broadband speeds have increased significantly in recent times. While a few Mbps was initially considered sufficient, businesses are now rapidly adopting speeds of 100 Mbps and higher, with the FCC setting a 25 Mbps benchmark for broadband. This shift signifies escalating bandwidth demands driven by the increasing reliance on remote resources and the changing nature of online content. What Does The New Standard Represent? The updated broadband standards highlight the growing need for greater bandwidth.

item.title: Cheaper Business Broadband Abounds
item.description: Due to budget constraints, many businesses are searching for cost-cutting measures that don’t negatively impact operations. Telecom and networking expenses are frequently targeted because they represent a significant monthly cost. It’s wise to examine these costs closely, as savings can often be found within your business broadband services. Some managers may believe their telecom costs are fixed and non-negotiable, a perception stemming from contracts signed years ago with the sole provider available at the time - usually the local telephone company.

item.title: Replacements for GigaMAN and Other Discontinued Line Services
item.description: By: John Shepler AT&T recently decided to discontinue certain line services due to a lack of demand. While this might not seem surprising, the services being phased out are not outdated copper lines, but rather relatively new, high-speed technologies: GigaMAN Gigabit Ethernet and DecaMAN 10 Gigabit Ethernet. These services are used to connect geographically dispersed Local Area Networks (LANs). Not So Old-Timey The discontinuation will affect customers in eleven states: Arkansas, California, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Oklahoma, Texas, and Wisconsin.

item.title: Last Mile Connections That Make Sense
item.description: The US is covered in a network of competing telecom companies, reaching into every major city. Businesses of all sizes are drawn to their advanced IP networks, fiber optic infrastructure, and significantly lower prices. But how can businesses connect to these networks? The final connection to a customer’s location, often called the “last mile,” is frequently the most critical, expensive, and limiting part of a wide area network. It gets its name from the typical distance between a business and the nearest carrier Point of Presence (POP).

item.title: Cloud Server vs Cloud Backup
item.description: Cloud backup services have gained immense popularity among both individuals and businesses. Most people store at least some files online for easy sharing and mobile access, exceeding the need for encrypted backups. Essentially, there’s a massive shift of data towards the cloud. While online file storage has become second nature, cloud computing hasn’t gained the same widespread adoption, despite a clear trend in that direction. However, there are strong indicators suggesting that cloud computing will reach a similar level of popularity as cloud storage within a few years.

item.title: Dedicated Bandwidth vs Cable
item.description: Businesses choose dedicated internet services, like T1 lines and Ethernet over Copper, when they prioritize consistent performance and service guarantees, or when shared options aren’t available. Cable broadband, on the other hand, attracts businesses with its high bandwidth for a lower cost. Although cable lacks service guarantees, its proven track record and widespread availability, especially during business hours, make it appealing. The term “dedicated” in this context signifies that a specific bandwidth amount is exclusively allocated to the user.

item.title: What is Ethernet WAN?
item.description: Ethernet WAN is the most significant advancement in business broadband since T1 service prices dropped. What exactly is Ethernet WAN, and why should you care? Ethernet has become the dominant standard for Local Area Networks (LANs). You could say that Ethernet is everywhere. An RJ45 Ethernet jack is standard on every desktop and laptop computer. You might not get a CD-ROM drive, probably won’t get a floppy disc drive, and may never use the phone modem jack again.

item.title: T1 Broadband For Rural Business
item.description: Government funding is being used to expand rural broadband access, as it’s generally understood that service providers have overlooked these areas due to their sparse populations. But what about businesses in these locations? Do they face similar internet limitations? In most cases, businesses in rural areas shouldn’t be deprived of reliable internet any more than they are deprived of multi-line phone service. The existing copper telephone lines can also deliver broadband.

item.title: Why Your Telecom Lines Should Be Switched Ethernet
item.description: By: John Shepler A significant shift is occurring in the telecom industry as traditional circuit-switched networks are being replaced with packet-switched networks. This change brings with it the widespread availability of Ethernet connections, extending from individual locations to the internet. However, some organizations are hesitant to move on from their reliable T1 lines and SONET fiber optic services. This begs the questions: why should they consider transitioning, and to what?

item.title: Business Internet Access Companies
item.description: Consumers access the internet in various ways, and businesses have similar options, along with some exclusive ones. Let’s explore the choices available for companies at their business locations. Popular consumer broadband choices include DSL and cable for stationary setups, and 3G for mobile use. 4G wireless is emerging, with providers like CLEAR offering it for both fixed and mobile applications. In remote areas, satellite broadband delivers connectivity where wires can’t reach.

item.title: Who Still Needs a T1?
item.description: Despite the buzz around copper and fiber Ethernet and advancements in cable broadband, the longstanding business connectivity solution, T1, receives little attention. This raises the question: Is T1 becoming obsolete or does it still hold relevance? T1 remains prevalent. New installations persist, demonstrating its enduring popularity. Its longevity, coupled with declining prices comparable to Ethernet over Copper services, contributes to its continued relevance. T1 is essential for businesses requiring dedicated professional-grade bandwidth, secure point-to-point connections, or reliable telephone trunking, particularly in remote locations with limited connectivity options.

item.title: Fixed Wireless Broadband Services For Business
item.description: Traditionally, business-grade telecom services rely on physical wires like copper or fiber optics. This often makes IT managers apprehensive when asked for immediate high-bandwidth internet access, point-to-point transmission, or VoIP telephone service, knowing that WAN networking rarely offers instant solutions. However, a solution called fixed wireless service is emerging as a viable option. Imagine having the same bandwidth services without the need for physical wires. This technology differs significantly from mobile phone services or short-range wireless access points.

item.title: What Ethernet over Copper Is All About
item.description: Ethernet over Copper (EoC) is an innovative business bandwidth service that surpasses traditional options like T1 and DS3 lines in terms of cost and performance. Businesses currently using these older services should consider switching to EoC due to its significant advantages. EoC leverages the Ethernet standard, widely used in local area networks, and extends it for metropolitan and wide area network transmission. Unlike traditional telecom services based on telephone technology, EoC utilizes a protocol directly compatible with computer networks, eliminating the need for complex interface cards and protocol conversions.

item.title: DS3 Internet Service Options
item.description: Mid-sized and larger businesses that have outgrown the capacity of T1 lines have turned to DS3 Internet Service as the next step in their telecommunications services. Currently, there are more choices for businesses, both small businesses with high bandwidth demands and larger companies seeking this service level. DS3, short for Digital Signal level 3, is a well-established telecommunications standard for transmitting digital data. It provides a reliable 45 Mbps bandwidth suitable for dedicated point-to-point connections, PBX telephone systems, or internet connectivity.

item.title: Fiber Optic Bandwidth is Closer Than You Think
item.description: By: John Shepler There are many more options for internet connectivity than there were just a few years ago. Don’t assume that T1 lines are the be-all and end-all without exploring your options. You might be surprised! Increased Bandwidth is Necessary Fiber optic bandwidth has been discussed as a future necessity for years. When you examine the applications that are most used by consumers and businesses, it is obvious that only fiber can accommodate their bandwidth requirements.

item.title: DS1 Bandwidth vs Ethernet
item.description: DS1, commonly called T1, is a popular choice for business internet. This article will explain DS1 and compare it to another popular option: Ethernet over Copper. While the terms are often used synonymously, DS1 and T1 are slightly different. They both come from a set of technical standards created by Bell Labs called the T-carrier system, which was originally a digital replacement for analog phone lines. Though designed for telephones, DS1 and T1 are now widely used for dedicated internet connections and private lines.

item.title: Business Broadband Options in Rural Areas
item.description: By: John Shepler Businesses located in bustling city centers have a wide array of broadband Internet options, unlike their rural counterparts. While the lack of service providers in less populated areas might make it seem like broadband is a luxury they can’t afford, there are actually several options available, depending on the location. Rural businesses might feel limited in their connectivity choices. Unlike their city counterparts, they don’t have numerous service providers vying for their business.

item.title: Bandwidth Cost Reduction Ideas
item.description: Getting the best price on everything your business buys is crucial for success, and bandwidth is no exception. Telecom expenses can be significant, but there are ways to save without sacrificing productivity. One surprisingly simple step is to get updated competitive quotes. Bandwidth prices change rapidly, so your current understanding might be outdated. While gathering quotes used to be time-consuming, online tools like GeoQuote by Telarus have simplified the process. This automated engine collects pricing from various providers, delivering budgetary quotes for services like T1, ISDN PRI, DS3, and Ethernet connections almost instantly.

item.title: How T1 Lines Support VoIP Telephony
item.description: T1 lines have historically been the top choice for connecting traditional PBX business phone systems. But how do they support VoIP phone systems used by enterprises? Many mid-size and large companies are integrating VoIP technology into their existing PBX systems. They’re installing new systems that combine voice and data, or even completely replacing outdated systems that are no longer cost-effective to maintain. This shift is driven by several well-known advantages: enhanced features that boost employee productivity, cost reductions from converging voice and data networks, and simplified system moves and upgrades.

item.title: Why T1 Is Available Where Other Line Services Aren’t
item.description: Businesses located outside of city centers may struggle to obtain the same quality of network services as their downtown counterparts. While it may seem like options are limited, a reliable and affordable digital telecom service called T1 is often accessible in these areas. Contrary to outdated beliefs, T1 lines are no longer prohibitively expensive or geographically restricted. They are widely available for businesses, though they may not be suitable for residential use.

item.title: How to Feed a Hungry WISP
item.description: By: John Shepler The United States is extensively wired, except in remote areas like farms, rural homes, businesses outside city limits, new developments, and some industrial parks. While universal service often provides phone access, broadband internet is less certain. This is where Wireless Internet Service Providers (WISPs) come in. Why WISPs? WISPs function like cell phone providers but focus on high-speed internet. Unlike 4G cellular data, which has low usage limits, WISPs offer generous data allowances similar to cable, telco, or fiber optic services.

item.title: Dedicated vs Shared Internet
item.description: By: John Shepler When choosing business internet services, bandwidth is important, but understanding the difference between dedicated and shared connections is crucial. What Does Dedicated Mean? Dedicated bandwidth is exclusively for your use. This might seem obvious, but the recent rise of shared bandwidth makes it worth clarifying. The cost-effectiveness of shared bandwidth often makes businesses reconsider their need for a dedicated line. Cost Considerations Shared bandwidth is significantly cheaper than dedicated bandwidth at similar speeds.

item.title: Technicians at Your Beck and Call
item.description: Smaller businesses may find it difficult to afford a full-time technical expert, especially in a tough economy. However, this doesn’t mean you have to postpone necessary telephone and network upgrades or settle for under-qualified technicians. You can get the expertise you need by hiring contractors. Focus on finding pre-screened professionals with experience in your required services instead of just any contractor. You only pay for the specific work done, often as part of a package deal that includes equipment, installation, setup, and training at a special price.

item.title: Voice over Internet Protocol Phone Services
item.description: The increasing popularity of Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) suggests it will likely replace traditional phone services, including landlines and ISDN PRI. This shift is primarily driven by the transition from traditional telephone networks to computer-based networks, further complicated by the emergence of wireless voice and data services. Telephone networks, largely analog during their long history, were initially designed solely for voice communication. While attempts were made to use them for data transfer with analog modems, the limited bandwidth of these networks proved insufficient for anything beyond low-speed data.

item.title: Ethernet over Copper Reviving The Local Loop
item.description: Local loop usage has decreased as people switch from traditional phone lines to wireless or internet-based phone services. This has prompted some to suggest that these copper lines be completely removed. However, just as this idea emerges, new technology is giving these old lines a new purpose. Fiber optic connections may be the future, but they’re not widely available yet. Only a small percentage of businesses currently have fiber, due to lack of demand, high installation costs, or limited infrastructure.

item.title: Free Telecom Consulting Service
item.description: In today’s economy, many companies are hesitant to hire consultants due to budget constraints. While consultants can potentially save money in the long run, the initial expense can be difficult to justify. So, how can businesses access consulting services without breaking the bank? The answer is free consulting. One company offers free technical consulting specializing in business telecommunications. By submitting an online inquiry or calling their toll-free number, businesses can connect with a consultant for immediate assistance.

item.title: Differences Between Fiber and EoC
item.description: Many businesses are analyzing if switching to fiber optic services is worthwhile due to limitations with their current internet and private line bandwidth. However, there’s now an additional choice: Ethernet over Copper (EoC). You might be surprised to learn that EoC’s bandwidth and affordability put it in a similar league as fiber optics. The traditional fiber optic service relies on the SONET (Synchronous Optical NETwork) standard, created by the telephone industry.

item.title: Data Caps: What They Are and How to Avoid Them
item.description: By: John Shepler If you’re a frequent internet user, you’ve probably encountered data caps. This article explains these usage limits and how to navigate them. OK, What IS a Data Cap? A data cap restricts the amount of data transferred over a connection within a specific timeframe. Usually set monthly, these limits, measured in MB or GB, reset every 30 days. Activities like browsing, file transfers, and cloud backups consume this data.

item.title: Use a Telecom Broker Before You Go Broker
item.description: Are you getting the best deal on your telecom services? It’s hard to know when every provider claims to offer the best rates. Comparing plans and prices from multiple companies is time-consuming and challenging. That’s where telecom brokers come in. Telecom brokers are independent experts who work on your behalf to find the best telecom deals. They are not affiliated with any specific provider, ensuring unbiased recommendations. Similar to independent insurance agents, telecom brokers represent multiple carriers, giving you access to a wide range of options.

item.title: Benefits of Migrating From T1 to Fiber
item.description: By: John Shepler While T1 lines have proven their reliability over decades, sticking with them solely due to past success might not be the best strategy. This article explores compelling reasons to consider alternatives. Why T1 Lines Were Once Favored T1’s strength lies in its established design and history. Developed for clear long-distance phone connections, T-Carrier technology, encompassing T1, E1, and T3 (DS3), evolved to handle data packets alongside voice calls due to its digital nature.

item.description: By: John Shepler Are you feeling stuck because your business needs internet, even if it’s just local? Have you considered cable and DSL but found them unavailable in your area? item.title: 100 Mbps Ethernet over Copper Rivals Fiber
item.description: Ethernet over Copper is quickly replacing T1 lines for low to medium bandwidth needs. While copper lines can reach speeds of 20 to 50 Mbps, Paetec now offers 100 Mbps Ethernet over Copper, eliminating the need for fiber optic service in many situations. For over a century, copper wires have connected central offices to telephones. While designed for low-frequency audio signals, clever engineering enables these existing copper lines to carry high-frequency digital signals.

item.title: Shopping For High Speed Options
item.description: The landscape of business broadband has undergone significant changes. While options were once limited and expensive, today’s market offers a variety of affordable high-speed solutions. For instance, T1 lines, previously exceeding $1,000, now cost around $300 for most locations and offer speeds of 1.5 Mbps or higher with bonding. An alternative, Ethernet over Copper (EoC), provides 2-3 Mbps at a similar price point and allows for easier scalability compared to T1’s jump to DS3.

item.title: Ethernet over Copper Data Service
item.description: While traditional data services rely on technologies like T1 lines, DS3 bandwidth, OC-3, SONET fiber optics, Frame Relay, and MPLS networks for connectivity, Ethernet over Copper (EoC) presents a modern alternative for the last mile. Although not available coast-to-coast, EoC provides a cost-effective, high-performance solution, especially for connecting businesses to larger private or public networks. EoC leverages existing copper infrastructure, eliminating the need for costly fiber optic installations or dealing with line-of-sight issues encountered with fixed wireless solutions.

item.title: California and Nevada Get 200 Mbps Bandwidth over Copper
item.description: The demand for business bandwidth has increased significantly over the past ten years. Companies that once relied on T1 lines (1.5 to 12 Mbps) or DS3 (45 Mbps) now require speeds exceeding 100 Mbps to accommodate high-definition video, large datasets, and cloud-based services. Obtaining up to 200 Mbps over multiple copper pairs is now much simpler for businesses in California and Nevada. While achieving such speeds with fiber optic connections (SONET or Ethernet over Fiber) is not difficult, the installation of fiber optic cables presents a significant obstacle.

item.title: A Myriad of Business Broadband Options
item.description: There are many choices for business broadband internet, even beyond options like DSL, 3G and 4G Wireless, Cable, Satellite, T1 lines, and Ethernet over Copper. These choices depend on if your business is small, medium, or large. However, no matter what they are physically made of (wireless, copper, coaxial cable, or fiber optic), they all boil down to two types: dedicated or shared broadband connections. Shared bandwidth options, like DSL, Cable, 3G & 4G Wireless and Satellite, are typically the cheapest.

item.title: Are T1 Lines Obsolete?
item.description: By: John Shepler Have you been relying on a T1 line for a long time? It’s understandable, given their long history. When the Internet was new, a T1 line provided businesses with a dependable, high-bandwidth connection that made dial-up modems seem incredibly slow. These days, similar bandwidth options are available at comparable prices, making those old T1 lines appear slow in comparison. So, are T1 lines still a viable business solution, or are they outdated?

item.title: Can You Save 50% On Telecom Costs?
item.description: Even with a tough economy, you might be overpaying for your business telecom services. Want a simple way to reduce your budget without sacrificing staff or essential services? We’ll explain how your company can potentially achieve a 50% cost reduction. Most businesses rely on two primary telecom services: telephone and broadband internet.

item.title: Bandwidth Management Gets Easier With Ethernet
item.description: The unpredictable nature of bandwidth demand, with its constant fluctuations and potential for rapid growth, presents a challenge for IT managers seeking to balance sufficient resources with cost-effectiveness. Traditional procurement processes, designed for less dynamic times, involve lengthy steps from identifying needs to service activation, making it difficult to adapt quickly to changing bandwidth requirements. This problem is exacerbated by legacy telecom services like T1 lines or OC connections, which offer fixed bandwidth levels.

item.title: Private Lines and Virtual Private Networks
item.description: By: John Shepler Businesses frequently require private lines for reliable and secure communication between various locations like headquarters, branches, factories, and suppliers. The goal is to create a seamless experience akin to a local area network. Traditional Point-to-Point Private Lines Private lines, essentially dedicated wires between two points, have existed for a long time. item.title: Copper While Waiting For Fiber
item.description: Fiber optic connections are the optimal choice for high bandwidth, offering speeds from 10 Mbps to 10 Gbps using either SONET or Carrier Ethernet protocols. However, accessing these options requires “lit” fiber service, which can take several months or more due to potential construction delays. So, how do you maintain connectivity in the meantime? While waiting for fiber activation was once the only option, many carriers now offer a two-stage solution for businesses needing immediate bandwidth.

item.title: MAN and MEN - Metropolitan Networking
item.description: Metropolitan Area Networks (MANs) are the solution for expanding local networks across different locations within a city. Unlike confined on-site wiring, MANs tackle the challenge of connecting across larger distances. Traditionally, businesses leased dedicated lines like T1 or DS3 from telecom companies to link their offices. However, this method proved costly and demanded self-management. MANs offer a practical alternative by providing shared fiber optic infrastructure, leading to cost savings and scalability for businesses.

item.title: VoIP Compatible High Speed Internet
item.description: The increasing popularity of Voice over IP (VoIP) among businesses is undeniable, primarily due to its advanced features and cost-effectiveness compared to traditional phone services. However, the transition to VoIP raises a crucial question: how to handle existing phone lines. This question arises because the traditional phone system, deeply rooted in analog technology, has long relied on copper wiring for transmission. While smaller companies might still use analog lines, larger businesses have often transitioned to digital transmission methods like ISDN PRI (also known as T1 PRI).

item.title: Business DSL Alternatives
WAN Connection Strategies
item.description: When you need to connect your business to the outside world, the variety of telecommunication options can be overwhelming. Understanding the basic technologies can help you make the right choice. There are two main types of networks: Time Division Multiplexing (TDM) and Internet Protocol (IP). TDM is older and relies on dedicated circuits, while IP uses packet switching for more flexible data transfer. Interestingly, both types can carry the other’s traffic, blurring the lines.

item.title: Ethernet Providers in Hot Competition
item.description: While demand for bandwidth increases, budgets remain tight. Ethernet WAN connections offer a new solution to this problem. This technology has become a strong alternative to traditional T1 lines, leading to fierce competition among Ethernet providers vying for the best deals. The buzz surrounding Ethernet, a protocol used in LANs for years, stems from its standardization as a carrier technology by the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF). This has propelled Ethernet services from LANs to MANs and WANs in just a few years, turning it from a niche product into the preferred transport service.

item.title: Covad Ethernet Now Cheaper Than T1
item.description: Prepare to be surprised! Covad is now offering Ethernet bandwidth at prices even lower than T1 solutions of comparable speeds. That’s right, the tide has turned, and Ethernet is now a more budget-friendly option. While this is an initial launch in 12 markets across California, Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, and Texas, it could be a sign of a nationwide shift in telecommunication pricing. To see if your location qualifies, you can check Ethernet availability online.

item.title: Ethernet In The First Mile
item.description: Global telecommunication companies are updating their networks from circuit-based to packet-based systems. With the growth of internet-based networks, Ethernet WAN services have become more accessible and affordable. However, businesses often still rely on older technologies like T1, DS3, or SONET for connecting to these services and cloud networks. While these older technologies are reliable and getting cheaper, using Ethernet for the initial connection, known as the “first mile” or “last mile,” offers several benefits.

item.title: 10x10 Mbps Ethernet Providers in Demand
item.description: By: John Shepler Many believe that 10 Mbps Ethernet is replacing traditional T1 lines, and for good reason. This article will explore why that is, how this technology works, and the steps to upgrade. Businesses have relied on T1 lines for decades due to their high reliability, guaranteed bandwidth of 1.5 Mbps, and symmetrical upload and download speeds. Prices have also decreased over time, and availability is now widespread. The main drawback of T1 lines is their limited bandwidth.

item.title: Broadband Ethernet Internet Services
item.description: Ethernet point-to-point and LAN services have gained popularity among businesses, often replacing T1 lines and outdated Frame Relay networks. Ethernet is also a great way to connect to MPLS VPN networks and the internet. Carrier Ethernet began as a business-oriented Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) service known as Metro Ethernet, often used by companies to connect multiple locations within a specific geographic region. E-Line point-to-point services like EPL and EVPL provide comparable or superior connectivity to T1 lines, even when multiple T1 lines are used.

item.title: Many Flavors of Business Internet
item.description: By: John Shepler Connecting your business to the internet is crucial in today’s world. It’s practically impossible to operate without a broadband connection. Customers, cloud services, backups, suppliers, and even connections to home offices or remote locations rely on it. The question is, how can you establish the best connection for your business? Businesses have numerous options for internet service, but the variety can be overwhelming. Choosing the cheapest option might leave you frustrated if it can’t handle your needs.

item.title: PRI Lines For Domestic Call Centers
item.description: Many companies are turning to domestic call centers, whether they are in-house or independent contractors. All call centers rely on telephone service, and PRI lines are the preferred choice. Let’s explore why. PRI, or Primary Rate Interface, belongs to the Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) standard. ISDN aimed to transition all telephone lines from analog to digital. The basic offering, BRI (Basic Rate Interface), provides two phone lines or one phone line with either a 64 Kbps or 128 Kbps data service.

item.title: Ethernet Everywhere? We’re Almost There!
item.description: By John Shepler For a while now, experts have predicted a future where all networking standards converge into one: Ethernet. We are nearing a reality where T1, DS3, OCx, and others will be obsolete. How close are we? Very close! Network Standards Already Favor Ethernet Telecommunications companies are embracing a once-unthinkable idea: they are replacing their proprietary standards with Ethernet services. The reason is simple: market demand. The past saw many Local Area Network standards.

item.title: T1 and EoC When There Is No Fiber
item.description: The future of business undoubtedly lies in fiber optic bandwidth, particularly given the surge in video content and the increasing shift towards cloud computing. item.description: Businesses often need to connect multiple offices, whether they are in the same city, different parts of the country, or even internationally. There are several ways to achieve this, each with its own set of advantages. One traditional method is a dedicated private line, such as a T1 line. These lines offer symmetrical bandwidth, meaning upload and download speeds are equal, which is crucial for business operations that involve heavy data transfer in both directions.

item.title: How Broadband Bonding is Mushrooming
item.description: Businesses with high bandwidth demands now have a delicious new option for boosting their WAN capacity thanks to the TRUFFLE from Mushroom Networks, Inc. What makes the TRUFFLE so appealing? This device can combine the bandwidth of multiple broadband connections – think DSL, Cable, T1, even satellite – to create a single, faster, and more reliable connection, similar to T1 line bonding but with more flexibility. The TRUFFLE BBNA6401 model, for instance, can aggregate up to 6 different connections, reaching download speeds of up to 50 Mbps.

item.title: Business VoIP Solution Options
item.description: If you’re thinking about switching your business phone system from the traditional analog or PBX setup to VoIP (Voice over Internet Protocol), it’s wise to explore the various business VoIP options available before making a complete overhaul. The best choice for you depends on your specific needs and, by selecting wisely, you can maximize your telephony investment. The main reasons to consider VoIP are cost savings, enhanced calling features, or a combination of both.

item.title: International Dedicated Internet Access
item.description: Businesses that rely heavily on the internet require dependable internet access, especially multinational companies that need consistent connectivity across all their locations. The internet’s robust infrastructure allows data to travel globally. If one path fails, the network automatically reroutes traffic. Performance issues often stem from local access networks rather than the internet’s core. While the internet excels in many areas, real-time processes like video conferencing can be affected by its inherent limitations.

item.title: Broadband Insurance Keeps You in Business
item.description: By: John Shepler Constant connectivity has its perks for individuals and businesses, but technology isn’t foolproof. A broadband outage can be incredibly isolating. Fortunately, there are safeguards against such situations. Consumers can utilize their mobile data as a backup. Modern smartphones can act as wireless hotspots, allowing devices like computers and printers to connect. While speed and data limits might be concerns, it provides a temporary solution. Another option is using public Wi-Fi hotspots, though availability might be an issue during widespread outages.

item.title: High Speed Internet For Business
item.description: In recent years, high-speed internet access has become widely available and affordable for businesses. Numerous broadband options exist, even in remote areas. Let’s explore a variety of high-speed internet connections, categorized by low, medium, and high bandwidth. While businesses might desire high bandwidth, most don’t require extremely high speeds. Generally, higher bandwidth means higher cost. However, prices within bandwidth categories can vary. Shared service options are less expensive than dedicated services but offer less stable bandwidth.

item.title: Vocal IP Networx Offers Free SNMP Monitoring
item.description: You’re likely familiar with the challenges of managing T1 lines and bandwidth, especially keeping track of service availability across different vendors and equipment. While large companies have dedicated IT teams, smaller businesses often handle this responsibility as issues arise. Wouldn’t it be beneficial to have affordable network monitoring support? Vocal IP Networx, a leading IP telephony provider, offers a solution: free, continuous SNMP monitoring for all circuits and customer premises equipment (CPE) they provide.

item.title: Can You Believe 200 Mbps EoC?
item.description: Ethernet over Copper (EoC) is a widely used technology that delivers mid-band Ethernet connections without the delays and costs of fiber optic installation. Although initially considered a temporary solution, EoC has become a strong competitor to fiber services. ](http://www.ethernetovercopper.co/)Businesses currently using T1 lines or considering them are a key market for EoC. T1 is a well-established, dependable, and cost-effective telecom service that offers 1.5 Mbps using one or two pairs of twisted copper telephone wiring.

item.title: Fiber Optic vs Copper 50 Mbps
item.description: Businesses that need to connect numerous employees to the internet or move large files, particularly high-resolution images, require more bandwidth than a standard connection provides. Traditionally, they’ve upgraded their T1 lines to DS3 service, which offers 45 Mbps. Now, there are more choices for around 50 Mbps using both copper and fiber optic connections. DS3 is often considered a copper wireline service because it connects with coaxial cables and uses BNC connectors.

item.title: Ethernet Bandwidth For Rural Areas
item.description: Contrary to popular belief, Ethernet WAN service isn’t confined to cities. There are ways to get Ethernet connectivity even in rural areas. Ethernet over Copper (EoC) is gaining popularity among small and medium businesses. It uses existing telephone wiring to deliver Ethernet speeds from 3 to 50 Mbps, and even over 100 Mbps in some places. This makes it a cost-effective option for businesses that need high bandwidth. However, EoC has distance limitations.

item.title: Gigabit Ethernet Replaces DS3 and T3
item.description: By: John Shepler T3 lines and DS3 bandwidth, once a cornerstone of telecom services, are becoming outdated with the emergence of newer technologies like Carrier Ethernet WAN, point-to-point microwave for business, and DOCSIS 3 cable broadband. Let’s explore the options available for your business in the 50 to 1000 Mbps speed range. Transitioning from Traditional Telco T1 Lines Bell Labs revolutionized long-distance digital transmission after World War II with their T-Carrier system, introducing T1 and T3 services.

item.title: Will Ethernet Crush DS3?
item.description: Companies needing more bandwidth than a 1.5 Mbps T1 line often upgraded to DS3, but its 45 Mbps speed was often more than they needed. A newer option, Carrier Ethernet (also known as Metro Ethernet), offers a more practical solution with scalable bandwidth at a often lower cost. Ethernet services are significantly less expensive than DS3 in some markets, costing up to 50% less. However, in areas where Ethernet isn’t widely available, prices may be comparable to DS3.

item.title: Give Yourself Enough Time to Save on Telecom Costs
item.description: Everyone wants to save money. In business, securing the best deal is a top priority. This is especially true for telecom services, where the goal is maximum service for minimal cost. Achieving this is possible with two key steps: knowing where to find the best deals and allowing sufficient time to implement the optimal solution. Finding the best deals has become significantly easier. Instead of sifting through phonebooks or tirelessly searching online, businesses can now contact telecom brokers representing numerous providers.

item.title: T1 or Better Internet Service
item.description: Are you frustrated with your business-grade DSL or Cable broadband despite opting for a supposedly higher-tier plan? Let’s explore why that might be happening and delve into alternative business broadband solutions for superior performance. DSL and Cable Internet services are not inherently flawed. Millions of users are content with their performance, especially considering the affordability factor. However, this is where the issue arises. Businesses are enticed by the cost-effectiveness of these options but are often let down by the lack of robust, telecom-grade performance.

item.title: Easy Migration from T1 to Ethernet
item.description: By: John Shepler Many long-time users of T1 lines are finding that the bandwidth is no longer sufficient for their needs. A logical upgrade for most businesses is Ethernet, which is easily and affordably implemented. Don’t Write Off T1 Yet Despite its age, the wide availability of T1 lines makes them a convenient option. Originally designed for the telephone industry, T1 lines were later adapted for computer communications. With 1.5 Mbps bi-directional capacity, T1 has long been the standard for small and medium businesses; however, this bandwidth is now considered barely broadband.
